exercises.name: Dumbbell Wrist Curl
exercises.description: The dumbbell wrist curl is an isolation movement that strengthens the forearm flexors, particularly the flexor carpi radialis and flexor digitorum muscles. In this variation, the forearm is supported on a flat bench, palm facing upward, with the wrist hanging off the edge. The wrist is flexed upward to lift the dumbbell, then lowered under control to the starting position. This is a staple exercise for building grip strength, enhancing wrist stability, and preventing overuse injuries.
steps: Sit on a bench with your feet flat on the floor.
Hold a dumbbell in your hand and rest your forearm on the bench with your wrist hanging off the edge, palm facing up.
Start with your wrist fully extended, allowing the dumbbell to roll toward your fingertips.
Flex your wrist upward as far as possible while keeping your forearm stationary on the bench.
Pause briefly at the top of the movement, focusing on squeezing your forearm muscles.
Slowly lower the weight back to the starting position, allowing a full stretch in the forearm.
Complete all repetitions with one arm before switching to the other.
tips: Keep forearm fully supported and still throughout the movement.
Use a full range of motion—let the dumbbell roll toward fingers at the bottom.
Avoid using momentum; lift under control.
Focus on squeezing the forearm at the top of each rep.
Start with light weights until you master the movement pattern.
If you experience any wrist pain, reduce the weight or check your form.
For added intensity, hold the contracted position for 1-2 seconds before lowering.
Ensure your grip is secure but not overly tight, as this can limit your range of motion.

exercises.name: Dumbbell Wrist Rotation
exercises.description: This is a forearm rotational control drill using a dumbbell held vertically by the end of its handle. It primarily trains the pronators and supinators of the forearm (pronator teres, supinator), as well as the muscles responsible for wrist radial and ulnar deviation. With the forearm braced on a bench and the wrist hanging free, the dumbbell is rotated slowly under control through its arc, resisting gravitational torque. This movement is key for strengthening rotational stability of the wrist and elbow—useful in sports, lifting, and injury prevention.
steps: Sit on a bench with your feet flat on the floor.
Hold a light dumbbell vertically by one end, with your forearm supported on the bench and your wrist hanging off the edge.
Keep your upper arm stationary and your elbow fixed at approximately 90 degrees.
Starting with your palm facing inward, slowly rotate your wrist to turn the palm upward (supination).
Continue through a controlled range of motion, rotating your wrist to turn the palm downward (pronation).
Move through the full range of rotation as comfort allows, focusing on controlled movement.
Perform additional movements by tilting the wrist side to side (radial and ulnar deviation) if desired.
Complete all repetitions with one arm before switching to the other.
tips: Move slowly and avoid jerking or over-rotating.
Keep the elbow and forearm locked to isolate the wrist.
Let the dumbbell's leverage do the work—don't overload it.
Emphasize smooth transitions and control in both directions.
Start with a very light weight—this exercise requires less weight than you might expect.
Focus on quality of movement rather than quantity of repetitions.
If you feel any pain (not just resistance), stop the exercise.
Maintain a neutral wrist position when not actively moving through the rotations.
contraindications: Recent surgery to wrist or forearm

exercises.name: Isometric Wrist Extension Hold (No Equipment)
exercises.description: A low-load isometric hold for wrist extensor tolerance that can be done at home without equipment. Place your affected forearm on a thigh or table, set the wrist in slight extension, and hold a steady position while keeping the shoulder and neck relaxed. This is useful in early-stage elbow tendon rehab when dynamic loading is not yet well tolerated.
steps: Sit with your forearm supported on your thigh or a table and your palm facing down.
Lift the back of your hand slightly into wrist extension using your other hand to assist if needed.
Hold the position steadily with light to moderate effort and relaxed breathing.
Keep your elbow and shoulder quiet while maintaining the hold.
Lower slowly and repeat.
tips: Keep pain mild and stable during the hold.
Do not grip hard with the fingers while holding.
Use shorter holds if symptoms increase the next morning.
Focus on steady tension rather than maximal effort.

exercises.name: Self-Resisted Forearm Rotation (No Equipment)
exercises.description: A controlled pronation/supination drill using your opposite hand for light resistance. This movement builds rotational tolerance around the wrist and elbow without requiring dumbbells or a bench.
steps: Bend your elbow to about 90 degrees and keep it close to your side.
Use your opposite hand to provide gentle resistance as you rotate the forearm palm-up.
Reverse direction with the same gentle resistance and rotate palm-down.
Move slowly through pain-free range and keep shoulder and trunk still.
Repeat for controlled reps on each side.
tips: Use very light resistance at first.
Keep the movement smooth with no jerking.
Stay in a pain-managed range.
Stop if symptoms become sharp or radiating.
